content.description: This is a fun looking climb, right before you go through the tunnel to the Cracked Egg, on an overhanging boulder full of slopey jugs and pockets. The feet are tricky on the start, and the moves are very reachy but not too hard if you have good upper body strength. Shorter climbers will love this problem! I don't know who FA'ed this, but it looks too good to have not been climbed!
content.location: Walk down the dry river bed all the way until you get to the tunnel. You have to crawl through to get to Cracked Egg. It is right before the tunnel. You can't miss it!

content.description: This one is easy and quite fun. Start below the obvious finger seam on the bulge with your left hand in a vertical crack and your right hand around the corner. Not using the large jugs near the start, work your way to the end of the lower seam and up/left to a second seam, all while staying off the rear arete. The second seam adds a star, but the initial jugs take away from the crackiness if used.
content.protection: A pad or two - this one traverses left a little.
content.location: On the right Cracked Egg, start on the far right on the bulge.

content.description: Begin right in front of where the bottom of the split occurs on the obvious "Cracked Egg" Boulder. Step right into the middle, and begin stemming on good ledges with friction-focused hands until you reach the limit between the two boulders in stemming. Adjust your feet, make a move to the right onto the face of the right boulder, and move upwards cruising on lichen covered slopers and okay crimps. Top out on the right side of the "Cracked Egg" Boulder, and walk down on the back farther to the climber's right until you are able to downclimb from the ledge between the boulders on the right side. It is worth the warm-up.
content.protection: 1-2 pads and a scratch pad for the inside middle of the boulder problem - not much.
content.location: It is the direct middle of the "Cracked Egg" Boulder.

content.description: Starting on a bomb-ass right hand and a cool, left pinchy thing, reach up to good divots (some are better than others) and top it out, like a professional climber with a shoe sponsor.
content.protection: Two pads are better than one.
content.location: This is on the upper boulder to the right of the right Cracked Egg.

content.description: This is an easy warm-up if you're craving an easy slab. Start with your left hand in the largest vertical crack and your right hand just around the corner of the bulge. Throw for some jugs on the right, use other smallish features to crawl up the slab, and top out. This is kind of tall yet significantly slabby - take a few breaths, and calm your mind.
content.protection: One pad works, two is better, three is better...
content.location: On the right Cracked Egg Boulder, your left hand starts in the vertical crack on the bulge propagating from the lower indent.

content.description: This one is a good one. Start on a left pocket and a lil nub around the right corner in the egg itself. Slap up the arete, and look out left for your sidepull of choice, then use underclings to get high feet, and find something good on the upper slab to get yourself up! Try to stay mostly on the "shell" if you're cool.
content.protection: Two pads are probably better than one, spotters are always nice.
content.location: The Great Lever is on the right arete of the left Cracked Egg.

content.description: This is a heavily-pocketed slab with unlimited pockets to choose from. Starting on pockets for hands and pockets for feet, climb up the slab using pockets, and top out.
content.protection: A pad is all that's needed.
content.location: This ascends a slab to the left of the dinosaur skull.
